project.name: Olam 2.0 - Malayalam Dictionary Platform Redesign
project.description: Complete reimagination of the Olam Malayalam-English dictionary platform with modern design, authentic Malayalam content, multi-source lexicographic data, and advanced linguistic features
project.objective: Create a comprehensive, user-friendly, and linguistically sophisticated Malayalam dictionary interface that prioritizes search functionality, presents multi-source dictionary data, and provides educational scaffolding for learners

core_principles: Search-first architecture: The search functionality must be the most prominent element on the page
Authentic Malayalam content: All user-facing content, examples, and VisuWords must be in Malayalam script
Multi-source aggregation: Present entries from multiple dictionaries (Gundert, Sabdatharavali, Bailey, Datuk, WordNet) with clear attribution
Educational scaffolding: Help users understand morphology, etymology, spelling correctness, and semantic relationships
Modern glassmorphism aesthetic: Use soft gradients, frosted glass effects, and layered depth
Accessibility and responsiveness: Mobile-first design with clear typography and color-coded information hierarchy

spelling_corrections.purpose: PRESCRIPTIVE - Teach correct orthography vs common errors

incorrect_forms.explanation: വാക്ക് + ് + ു is redundant. The word ends with a geminated consonant ക്ക് followed by inherent vowel, no need for ു sign.
The final vowel should be the inherent അ (് + schwa), not ു. വാക്കു changes pronunciation to 'vākku' which is incorrect.
The consonant ക should be geminated (ക്ക) to represent the long /kː/ sound. വാക് is incomplete.

design_iteration_history.rationale: User requested complete reimagination of Olam 2.0

design_iteration_history.change: Moved search to prominent hero section
design_iteration_history.rationale: User feedback: 'bring the word search option to the top of the page...make it appear prominent'
User requirement: 'everything looks perfect except for visuwords...entries must be in Malayalam'
User provided real dictionary entry: 'this is the entry from Sabdatharavali (STV)'
User question: 'how do we present a word if a word appears in more than one dictionaries?'

design_iteration_history.change: Added etymology, morphology, relations, spelling features
design_iteration_history.rationale: User request: 'add...etymology info, morphology parsing, related entries, similar spellings'
User requirement: 'add a section on incorrect spellings...വാക്ക് (correct), വാക്കു്, വാക്കു (incorrect)'

key_insights: Dictionary users expect search to be THE primary action - don't bury it in navigation
Authentic content builds trust - use real dictionary entries, not placeholder text
Malayalam script must be prominent and well-rendered - this is a Malayalam dictionary first
Multi-source presentation requires careful UI design to avoid overwhelming users - separate cards work better than merged definitions
Educational scaffolding (morphology alerts, etymology, spelling corrections) transforms a dictionary into a learning tool
Visual hierarchy through color (green=correct, red=error, orange=related, teal=linguistic info) aids quick scanning
Prescriptive (corrections) and descriptive (variants) features serve different user needs and should be separated
Glassmorphism with soft gradients creates modern feel while maintaining readability
Responsive design must prioritize mobile search experience - Malayalam typing on mobile is common

olam_3_vision.overview: Future research directions for Olam 3.0 that reimagine dictionary architecture and leverage artificial intelligence

concept_1_modular_dictionary_data.vision: Dictionary data as pluggable, composable modules rather than monolithic databases
concept_1_modular_dictionary_data.core_idea: Treat each dictionary source (Gundert, STV, Bailey, WordNet, etc.) as an independent module that can be loaded, unloaded, updated, or extended without affecting the core platform
architectural_principles: Microservices for lexicographic data - each dictionary is a separate API endpoint or data package
Version control for dictionary modules - Git-like versioning for tracking changes to lexical data
Hot-swappable sources - users can enable/disable dictionaries on the fly
Community-contributed modules - third-party dictionaries can be published and installed like npm packages
Standardized module schema - all dictionaries expose data through common interface (JSON-LD, TEI, LIFT)
Dependency management - dictionaries can depend on other dictionaries (e.g., etymological dictionary depends on historical dictionary)

technical_implementation.module_format: Each dictionary as npm-style package with package.json metadata
technical_implementation.module_registry: Central registry like npm/PyPI for Malayalam dictionary modules
technical_implementation.loader_system: Dynamic import() for lazy-loading dictionary data on demand
technical_implementation.caching_strategy: Service workers cache frequently used modules, IndexedDB for offline access
technical_implementation.api_specification: OpenAPI/GraphQL schema for standardized dictionary queries across all modules
technical_implementation.versioning: Semantic versioning (1.0.0) for dictionary data updates
technical_implementation.conflict_resolution: When multiple modules define same word, UI presents all definitions with source attribution (already implemented in Olam 2.0 multi-dictionary view)

user_benefits: Customizable experience - enable only the dictionaries you trust or need
Faster load times - only download modules you use
Offline functionality - cache preferred dictionaries locally
Domain-specific modules - install medical, legal, or technical Malayalam dictionaries as separate modules
Historical snapshots - revert to older dictionary versions for historical research
Experimentation - try community dictionaries without committing to them
developer_benefits: Distributed contribution model - anyone can publish a Malayalam dictionary module
Independent updates - fix bugs in one dictionary without rebuilding entire platform
A/B testing - compare different dictionary sources side-by-side
API-first design - dictionaries can be used in any application, not just Olam
Reduced maintenance burden - dictionary maintainers own their own modules
Innovation acceleration - new dictionary types (audio, video, sign language) can be added as modules

governance_model.core_modules: Maintained by Olam foundation - guaranteed quality and availability
governance_model.community_modules: Published by third parties - rating and review system
governance_model.verification_badges: Verified modules meet quality standards (accuracy, completeness, format)
governance_model.dispute_resolution: Academic board reviews contested definitions or etymologies
governance_model.deprecation_policy: Modules can be marked deprecated but remain available for backward compatibility

research_questions: How to handle contradictory definitions across modules?
What metrics determine module quality and trustworthiness?
How to incentivize community module creation while maintaining quality?
Can machine learning automatically merge similar entries from different modules?
How to preserve attribution while presenting unified search results?
What's the optimal balance between module granularity and user complexity?

concept_2_ai_era_dictionary.vision: Leverage artificial intelligence to transform the dictionary from static reference to intelligent language partner
concept_2_ai_era_dictionary.core_idea: AI doesn't replace lexicographers—it amplifies their work and personalizes the learning experience for each user

1_contextual_definition_selection.capability: AI determines which sense/definition to show based on user's context
1_contextual_definition_selection.use_case: User searches 'വാക്ക്' while reading a legal document → AI prioritizes legal sense ('testimony, statement') over general sense ('word')
1_contextual_definition_selection.implementation: NLP analysis of surrounding text, user's reading history, domain detection
1_contextual_definition_selection.benefit: Reduces cognitive load—no more manually scanning through 8 definitions to find the right one

2_personalized_learning_paths.capability: AI creates custom vocabulary learning sequences based on user's proficiency and goals
2_personalized_learning_paths.use_case: Learner wants to read Malayalam news → AI suggests high-frequency journalism vocabulary in optimal learning order
2_personalized_learning_paths.implementation: Spaced repetition algorithm, CEFR level tracking, goal-based curriculum generation
2_personalized_learning_paths.benefit: Accelerated language acquisition with personalized pacing

3_intelligent_example_generation.capability: LLM generates contextual example sentences when dictionary lacks them
3_intelligent_example_generation.use_case: Old dictionary entry has definition but no examples → AI creates 3-5 example sentences showing usage
3_intelligent_example_generation.implementation: Fine-tuned Malayalam GPT model, human review before publication, community voting on quality
3_intelligent_example_generation.benefit: Every word has rich contextual examples, not just high-frequency words

4_semantic_search_beyond_keywords.capability: Search by meaning, not just by spelling
4_semantic_search_beyond_keywords.use_case: User searches 'what do you call someone who never gives up' → AI returns 'അചഞ്ചലം' (steadfast), 'സഹിഷ്ണു' (patient), 'ദൃഢനിശ്ചയം' (determination)
4_semantic_search_beyond_keywords.implementation: Semantic embeddings (sentence-transformers), vector similarity search, Malayalam BERT

conclusion.summary: This JSON prompt documents the complete reimagination of Olam 2.0, a Malayalam dictionary platform that prioritizes search functionality, authentic Malayalam content, multi-source lexicographic data aggregation, and educational linguistic features. The design employs modern glassmorphism aesthetics with a carefully crafted color hierarchy (indigo for dictionary content, teal for linguistic features, green for correct forms, red for errors, orange for discovery). The implementation progressed through 7 major iterations based on user feedback, resulting in a comprehensive, accessible, and linguistically sophisticated dictionary interface. Additionally, this document captures the vision for Olam 3.0, exploring two revolutionary concepts: modular dictionary architecture and AI-powered intelligent language assistance.
